How to file Crypto ITR? ITR filling TUTORIAL for CRYPTO INVESTORS | Crypto Tax | Income Tax Return"
Transcript: "(00:00) Rs 15,790 Cr This is the amount which the Indian Government has tracked By taking 1% TDS on all Crypto Transactions Yes! In the last Financial Year, The government collected 157.9 Cr from TDS Which accounts for 1% Of every transaction. This means, after 1 July, 2022 If you have done any transaction in Crypto Then it will reflect on your 26AS If any transaction of Crypto If you have earned profit Then it is mandatory for you to file Tax There is no basic exemption of 2. (00:32) 5 Lakhs If you have incurred an overall loss Then this loss Against that particular transaction profit You can offset that Assume, your Crypto loss is in Lakhs But, in a particular transaction, overall, you have earned Rs 10,000 in profit And the same Rs 10,000 You have earned total in the year Even then Tax liability would be levied on you And Income Tax department is extremely serious about this Last year when through TDS, there was no tracking done Even then, Crypto-related notices were sent to 700 people The number will be higher this year too. (01:01) Because, through TDS every transaction has been tracked And one important thing Crypto is now in PMLA i.e Under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act has been added under the amendment. Any Crypto transaction Whether it's trade, swap or sell Or If you are buying any goods in that That will come under PMLA i. (01:22) e If you haven't done any proper compliance under this Then heavy penalties and action can be taken against you I am not saying all of these things to scare you. In fact, I am stating this to make you aware In today's video, we will cover Everything you need to know about Crypto Taxation Plus, in the same video On How to File Crypto Tax I will share an easier method of that too Jagruk Janta My name is RJ i. (01:43) e Rishabh Jain You are watching Labour Law Advisor If you haven't subscribed to the channel Then do it And surely press the bell icon [Intro Music] Before moving ahead, I would like to thank our sponsor for today: ClearTax Who have developed a Phenomenal product Which is India's only End-to-end Crypto Filing Portal This portal of Clear Tax 100+ exchanges i. (02:10) e Binance, CoinDCX, MudraX Compiles the data from everywhere Quite easily Mentions about Tax computation to you. And wherever there are Tax saving opportunities It does the computation automatically After this, directly via Clear Tax You can file a complete ITR And it is so easy to use this product First time taxpayers, students, everyone can easily file their return on this The link to register is in the pinned comment Do check it out Through ClearTax, your Crypto Games By declaring that How can you file your ITR We will have a discussion towards the end of the video (02:41) CRYPTO = VDA As you know Between Crypto and Government There hasn't been much co-ordination In 2013, RBI initially got the notification Investment should not be done in Crypto This is not safe After that, the Government introduced a ruling wherein the Banks were told to stop Crypto transactions Later, the decision was overturned in Supreme Court Finally, in 2022 - 23 Budget Government introduced all the rules and regulations The ones who govern the Taxation of Crypto. (03:10) In this, the Government told a very important thing. They told Crypto is not a currency. Because, only the Central Bank can issue a currency And all the Cryto, NFT, etc They termed it as Virtual Digital Assets VDA Tax Calculation Now as this is an asset It's Selling, Trading, Swapping Or else by purchasing any goods against it The gain that we receive That is known as Capital Gain. (03:34) Capital Gain means Your Sale Price - Purchase Price Let's understand this with an example Assume there is an Investor RJ He bought 2 coins Andy coins worth Rs 1L & Mandy coins worth Rs 1L After a while, the value of Andy coins becomes 0 And the value of Mandy coins exceeds to Rs 2L And he sells both these coins. (03:56) He sells Andy coins for Rs 0 And sells Mandy coins for Rs 2L So, in the Andy coins His Cost price, i.e Cost of Acquisition That was Rs 1L Sale Price was 0 i.e Capital Gain became: - Rs 1L That means a loss of Rs 1L Therein, in the case of Mandy Coin Sale Price was of Rs 2L Rs 1L was our Cost of the Acquisition i.e Our Capital Gain formed Rs 1L. (04:21) Now, this Capital Gain of Crypto Under the Income Tax Act section It is taxed based on 30% rate That means, whichever Capital Gain is forming 30% Tax will be levied on that If the Capital Gain is of Rs 100, then Rs 30 as Tax And this has been applied from FY 2022 - 23 This means from 1 April 2022 - 31 March 2023 All your Crypto Transactions The Capital Gain received on them. (04:45) The tax on that If the deadline gets extended beyond 31 July 2023 Then you need to file before that deadline. CASE STUDIES Now let's understand this concept in detail Through a few questions. Assume RJ Investor has bought several Cryptos Has bought BTC, has bought Ether But, has not sold So If he hasn't sold, then does he have to pay Tax Then answer is No When you sell an Asset Then a Capital Gain is realised on that The tax that is levied is only levied on the Realised Capital Gain If you have kept it on hold Then you don't have to pay any tax on that (05:21) - "Where is our money?" - "That's the best part - It's on the Batman Flash Drive On your keychain. - You have had it in your pocket all along". Now assume that Your RJ Investor His Total Income is below Rs 2.5L Assume he earns Rs 1.5L from Salary And earns an Income Rs 10K - Rs 20K from Crypto. So whether Tax will be levied on this case Or will he get an exemption of Rs 2.5L. (05:45) The answer is Rs 2.5L exemption He won't receive for Crypto Gains The Income that he is received from Crypto Assume there is a Capital Gain of Rs 20,000 Then he has to pay tax on that Rs 20,000 Now the 3rd question which is very interesting As I told you in my example initially To RJ, with respect to Andy coin and Mandy coin He incurred loss on Andy coin And he has earned profit only on Mandy coin. (06:08) If we check this overall Then he invested Rs 2L And now he has Rs 2L i.e overall no profit no loss situation So, does he have to pay Tax in such a situation The answer is Yes Their Income Tax Act states that Any loss connected to Crypto You cannot offset that That means, Rs 1L gain earned from Mandy coin On that you will have to pay Rs 30,000 tax But Rs 1L loss incurred on Andy coin The Income Tax department has no connection with it - If you have done 5 Trades On different currencies. (06:38) On 1, there has only been a profit of Rs 1,000 On everything else, you have incurred losses Rs 1L each Cumulatively, you incurred a loss of Rs 4L But still you have to pay a tax of Rs 10,000 Why has the Government kept it This could also be interesting for the audience That Now Crypto has not been streamlined in the Financial streams. (06:58) Whichever, normal currencies are there or trading Government requires that the fraudulent activities They should be curbed And it is estimated in the further that once all of this is financially streamlined That in this A lot of rules will be changed Next question A lot of you'll might have watched our Tax videos They know that Capital Gain are of 2 types Short Term Capital Gain - Long Term Capital Gain What will happen in the case of Crypto? Assume I have held my Crypto for a long time. (07:26) So now I am selling them Will I get the benefit of Long Term capital gain? The answer is No In Crypto, for Short Term or Long Term There is no different rate Whichever could be your Capital Gain Tax will be levied based on 30% rate Now, few intelligent people will say I haven't sold Crypto against INR I have only swapped it Assume I had BTC I converted that into Ether Or I converted that into Stable Coin I didn't receive any money So, do you have to pay Tax in this case too The answer is Yes! If you swap your Crypto (07:59) If you are converting it from one currency to a different currency Then, you technically consider this as That you initially converted your BTC into INR From that INR, you bought Ether In this case, whichever Capital Gain you are receiving On that sale of BTC It has been realised And you will have to pay Tax on that And lastly, If you are buying a product from Crypto Then, while purchasing that product The rate on which you bought Crypto On a higher rate, you are processing the payment, while buying the product (08:27) On that, you will have to pay Tax In conclusion, If you have traded on Crypto If you have swapped Crypto If you have purchased anything from Crypto In all these cases, All the Capital Gain that you have You need to pay 30% tax on that Apart from this, you won't get any benefits on exemptions/ deductions. That means, even If you have a little bit of Capital Gain in Crypto Even then, your Tax liability will be applicable And I had mentioned initially in the video That Government is able to track all your transactions (08:57) via TDS We will talk about that shortly in the video. Hence, it's very important Watch this video until the end All this was about trading Now, let's talk about By other means If I have earned Crypto. I don't mean by paying money. I have received Crypto from other means So, where I receive Crypto from? I might receive it through Gift. (09:13) I might receive it through Salary. I might receive it against Professional Services. I might get it through mining I might get it through staking AirDrop. Or else I created an NFT and launched it In this way, I could receive Crypto in such forms Through such cases, How will the Tax be levied? Firstly, let's talk about GIft And later we will talk about everything else In the case of Gift There is a simple exemption If you are accepting the gift From your Non-Blood relatives Then you don't have to pay Tax on the 1st 50,000 (09:43) i.e your Rs 50,000 Gift will be exempt I took Rs 50,000 from Rohan Via Crypto As a gift Then I don't have to pay any tax on that. But, If I took anything above Rs 50,000 Then I will have to pay tax on that. But, in the case of Blood relative Assume that You got Crypto from your parents as a gift Then there is no limit on that. (10:02) Now, in any other means Whether it's Salary, Professional Income, Staking, Mining Or through NFT If you have received any additional income. Then all of it is taxable Now how much tax will be levied on this rate Then, few professionals state that That you add this to your Income And file tax as per your Slab But, as per my understanding And we have spoken to a lot of experts They have told us That you have to pay tax based on 30% Assumed, you mined few Cryptos and you received Bitcoins worth Rs 20,000 After mining (10:35) Then on that Rs 2000, you have to pay Tax on the basis of 30% Assume, you received a gift worth Rs 1L in Crypto Then after deducting Rs 50,000 Then on the remaining Rs 50,000 You have to pay Tax on the basis of 30% There is another interesting thing in this Assume you received Bitcoin worth Rs 1L You removed Rs 50,000 before After that, on the remaining Rs 50,000 You paid tax on the basis of 30% After that, this Crypto of Rs 1L You spent for Rs 2L. (10:59) The capital gain that you have received after that Even then you have to pay 30% tax Now, let's talk about those few transactions. Wherein there is no Tax levied on Crypto Firstly, a Crypto Hold You HODL it (to buy-and-hold indefinitely) There will be no Tax levied on that From one wallet of yours to another If you are transferring your Crypto Then no tax will be levied on that If overall in a single Financial year You have received Crypto less than Rs 50,000 as a gift You don't have to pay any tax on that And from blood relatives (11:25) If you are receiving any amount of Gift In Crypto Then no tax is to be paid on that Now, let's talk about How does the Government track every transaction? So the Government is tracking this transaction via TDS. After 1 July 2022, Government has levied TDS on Crypto's sale amount Assume, RJ The Investor has sold his Bitcoins worth Rs 1L By visiting any Exchange Then I will only receive Rs 99,000 in return And Rs 1,000 as a TDS Will be deposited against my PAN Which will be reflected in my Form 26AS. (11:55) This means Few tax on your behalf Of Crypto has already been deducted against your PAN has been deposited with the Income Tax Department. So If overall In loss or any other transaction If you have not earned any profit Because, this TDS is also deducted in a loss transaction So, If you file your return Then you will get a refund on this amount Then, you understood TDS on Crypto You have understood Tax on Crypto Now the question arises For the Crypto to reflect in Income Which ITR form should we file? So If you file through Clear Tax (12:26) Then automatically the right ITR Form will be selected. But, for your information If you show Crypto as a Capital Gain Then you will file ITR 2 But, If you show it as a Business Income Then ITR 3 should be filed Note that in both the cases The tax rate would be 30% And after showing your Business Income You cannot claim any expenses on this Now, we will talk about Via Clear Tax Portal How will you be able to file your Crypto Taxation very easily? I am providing you the link in the pinned comment. (12:54) Visit the website and simply sign in via Google And you will get a list of a lot of Crypto Exchanges Binance, CoinDCX, MudraX, CoinSwitch In this, in whichever 1 or 2 If you have done transactions in your exchanges. By clicking on it. Via API Key or Via a FIle upload You can add all your transactions here Through this API Key How are you supposed to extract the data? Or How are you supposed to upload the file? It's PDF guide On every Exchange page You will get it for download After Importing the file Or after importing the date through the API (13:28) Your Overall P&L Of Crypto, will be reflected to you And after moving step by step ahead How much Tax is forming on that That will also be shown to you Apart from this, If you have any other transaction Which have not happened on these exchanges You can report those here too So Friends! How did you like this episode? Definitely mention in the comments below If you have any questions Even then mention them in the comments Either LLA Team or Clear Tax Team will try to give an answer to you And On Clear Tax, you will find the Tax filing link (13:55) So I am your Jagruk RJ Rishabh! Thank you so much for giving your precious time
output:
Summary of "How to File Crypto ITR?"
Crypto Tax Collection (00:00 - 01:01)

Indian Government collected ₹157.9 Cr via 1% TDS on crypto transactions.
Since July 1, 2022, all crypto transactions reflect in Form 26AS.
Tax filing is mandatory for crypto profits, with no basic exemption.
Last year, 700 people received crypto-related tax notices; numbers expected to rise.
Crypto Under PMLA (01:01 - 01:22)

Crypto transactions (trade, swap, sell, or use for purchases) now fall under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA).
Non-compliance can lead to heavy penalties and legal action.
Crypto Tax Calculation & Capital Gains (03:10 - 04:45)

Crypto is classified as a Virtual Digital Asset (VDA) and taxed as capital gains.
30% tax applies to all crypto profits, with no deductions or exemptions.
Losses from crypto cannot be offset against gains.
Case Studies & Taxation Rules (05:21 - 07:59)

Holding crypto (without selling) incurs no tax.
Crypto gains are taxable even if the total income is below ₹2.5L.
Swapping crypto (BTC to ETH) is taxable, as it's treated as a sale.
No distinction between short-term & long-term gains; flat 30% tax applies.
Gifts, Salary, and Other Crypto Income (09:13 - 10:59)

Crypto gifts below ₹50,000 from non-blood relatives are tax-free.
Crypto gifts from blood relatives (parents, siblings) are fully tax-exempt.
Income from mining, staking, salary, or airdrops is taxed at 30%.
Even after paying tax on gifted crypto, future sales will also be taxed.
Exemptions (10:59 - 11:25)

No tax if:
Crypto is HODL'd (not sold).
Transferring between your own wallets.
Gifts below ₹50,000 from non-blood relatives.
TDS on Crypto Transactions (11:25 - 11:55)

1% TDS deducted at source on all crypto sales.
Reflected in Form 26AS under the investor's PAN.
Loss transactions also attract TDS, but can be claimed as a refund.
ITR Filing for Crypto (12:26 - 12:54)

ITR-2 if shown as capital gains.
ITR-3 if shown as business income.
30% tax applies in both cases; expenses cannot be claimed.
Filing Crypto Tax via ClearTax (12:54 - 13:55)

ClearTax offers an automated crypto tax filing solution.
Users can import transactions from exchanges via API/file upload.
Computes taxable profits and assists in filing the correct ITR form.

output:
Summary of "SHAADI - A Standup Comedy Video by Aanchal Agrawal"
Joint Family Struggles (00:02 - 01:12)

Aanchal, born in a Marwari joint family, humorously describes the burden of being the youngest child, often treated like unpaid household help.
Elders in the family are too busy with their own disputes to properly raise kids.
Sisterly Conflicts (01:40 - 02:10)

Aanchal narrates her tough relationship with her elder sister, who enjoyed making her life miserable, from stealing her toys to setting her up for beatings.
Family Gatherings & Fufa Ji’s Outrage (02:43 - 03:19)

Aanchal recounts an incident where she casually mentioned going to the washroom, angering her conservative uncle (fufa ji), who found it inappropriate.
She mocks how fufa ji always has unnecessary complaints, even about food.
The Infamous "B-Word" Incident (03:48 - 05:23)

Her sister tricks her into saying an expletive about fufa ji in front of the whole family.
The room falls silent, and Aanchal's mother prepares to punish her but is interrupted by fufa ji’s demand to get the elder sister married before she "goes out of hand."
The Irony of Fufa Ji’s Concerns (05:56 - 06:27)

Aanchal humorously exposes fufa ji’s hypocrisy—despite his own embarrassing habits (like his constantly exposed "gullak" a.k.a. ass crack), he worries about the girls' manners.
Sister’s Marriage Prospects (07:03 - 08:04)

The family rushes to arrange the elder sister’s marriage, even debating whether she should first marry a tree or a dog due to astrological concerns.
A desperate groom arrives with sindoor in his pocket, ready to marry instantly.
Checklist for a Bride (08:33 - 09:59)

The groom’s family checks if the bride is soft-spoken, intact (physically "sealed"), and fair-skinned—highlighting the absurd expectations in arranged marriages.
Marriage Negotiations & Dowry (10:04 - 11:48)

The groom's family downplays dowry demands, saying they only want the bride with two sets of clothes—delivered in a Mercedes.
The bride's family hilariously scrambles to arrange the luxury car by breaking piggy banks and even shaking fufa ji upside down.
The Struggles of Maruti 800 (12:32 - End)

The newlyweds are gifted an old Maruti 800 instead, a car so basic that even Maruti didn’t bother to add airbags, implying that survival was optional.
The family hilariously overcrowds the small car, making it impossible for the couple to have any privacy, even on their honeymoon.

output:
Omega-3 Fatty Acids:

Omega-3 levels, measured via the Omega-3 Index (red blood cell test), are linked to reduced all-cause mortality, particularly cardiovascular disease.
High doses of EPA/DHA from marine sources show protective effects against heart disease.
Protein Intake Timing:

Consuming protein in the morning is critical to prevent muscle breakdown due to overnight fasting.
Breakfast should include amino acids for optimal muscle preservation.
Exercise and Longevity:

Exercise, especially high-intensity interval training (HIIT), significantly improves cardiovascular health and VO2 max.
Resistance training for 30–60 minutes weekly also provides substantial benefits.
Sauna Use:

Regular sauna sessions (4–7 times per week) at ~174°F are associated with reduced all-cause mortality and cardiovascular benefits.
Combining sauna use with exercise amplifies health benefits.
Nutritional Essentials:

A diverse diet rich in whole foods is essential for optimal health.
Key nutrients include B vitamins, zinc, iron (from red meat), and omega-3s.
Postprandial Glucose Response:

Managing blood glucose levels after meals is critical for mental clarity and reducing inflammation.
Walking post-meal can aid digestion and glucose management.
Inflammation and Brain Health:

Exercise reduces inflammation, improving mood and preventing cognitive decline.
Lactate produced during exercise serves as an energy source for the brain.
Cold Exposure and Fat Adaptation:

Cold exposure promotes "browning" of fat, increasing energy expenditure and heat production.
Resistance Training Guidelines:

Effective rep ranges for muscle growth: 6–30 reps with 1–3 reps in reserve at the end of a set.
Working with a coach can help avoid injuries and optimize performance.
General Health Tips:

Regular physical activity, balanced nutrition, and managing inflammation are key to longevity.
Small, consistent lifestyle changes (e.g., daily movement, nutrient-rich meals) have cumulative benefits..

output:
Neurogenesis and Brain Regeneration

Contrary to outdated beliefs, brain cells can regenerate, and the rate of regeneration affects cognitive function as we age.
Neurogenesis primarily occurs in the hippocampus, which is linked to memory, learning, and problem-solving.
Key Strategies for Boosting Brain Health

Exercise: Regular aerobic exercise enhances oxygen flow and supports brain health. Mix aerobic activities with high-intensity and long walks for best results.
Fasting: Intermittent and prolonged fasting stimulates brain repair and growth by reducing oxidative stress and promoting ketone production.
Cold and Heat Therapy: Cold exposure (e.g., ice baths, cold showers) and heat exposure (e.g., saunas) stimulate neurogenesis.
Dietary Recommendations

Omega-3 Fatty Acids: Found in fish oil and cod liver oil, these are essential for brain health, particularly DHA.
Low-Carb Diet: Reducing refined carbs and sugars minimizes oxidative stress and supports neuron energy needs via ketones.
Choline-Rich Foods: Egg yolks, organ meats, and fish are critical for acetylcholine production, a key neurotransmitter.
Probiotics and Gut Health: Fermented foods and diverse vegetables promote a healthy gut microbiome, positively affecting brain function.
Nutrients and Supplements

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Essential for brain function and reducing inflammation.
Zinc: Crucial for hippocampus health and cognitive function.
Phytonutrients: Found in green tea, turmeric, and other plant-based sources, these provide antioxidants to protect the brain.
Lifestyle Adjustments

Sleep: Quality sleep is essential for brain regeneration; insomnia and excessive caffeine can hinder this process.
Sun Exposure: Infrared light and vitamin D from sunlight enhance brain health and melatonin production.
Avoiding Harmful Substances

Limit oxidized oils (e.g., vegetable oils) and prioritize stable fats like coconut oil, lard, and butter.
Avoid excessive caffeine, which can overstimulate and harm cognitive function.
Evolutionary Perspective

Activities like fasting, cold exposure, and exercise align with ancestral survival mechanisms that sharpened brain function.
Call to Action

Incorporate as many of these practices as feasible into your lifestyle for improved brain health and neuron regeneration.

Fibonacci Retracements (00:00 - 00:27)

Identifies key support and resistance levels using Fibonacci numbers.
Common reversal level: 0.382 Fibonacci.
Combine with other signals for better entry.
Breakout Patterns (00:27 - 00:59)

Sudden price movement after consolidation.
Key patterns: wedges, triangles, rectangles.
Reversal Patterns (00:59 - 01:29)

Counter-trend movements, predicting reversals.
Notable patterns: double/triple tops and bottoms, head and shoulders, cup and handle.
Elliot Wave Theory (01:29 - 02:38)

Market moves in five-wave sequences.
Rules: Wave 2 < Wave 1; Wave 3 is longest; Wave 4 > Wave 1 peak.
Fair Value Gaps (02:38 - 03:15)

Gaps from buying/selling imbalances act as magnets for price revisits.
Candlestick Patterns (03:15 - 03:48)

Engulfing, hammer, shooting star, and Doji patterns signal price behavior.
Specialized Indicators

Heikin Ashi (03:48 - 04:19): Smooths trends, reduces noise.
Moon Phases (04:19 - 04:54): New moon = bullish; full moon = bearish.
Renko Charts (04:54 - 05:24): Blocks based on price changes, filtering noise.
Harmonic Patterns (05:24 - 06:21)

Predicts movements using Fibonacci-based shapes (e.g., butterfly, bat, crab).
Support, Resistance, and Trend Lines (06:21 - 07:24)

Key levels for buy/sell opportunities.
Dynamic levels use moving averages; trendlines show market direction.
Momentum and Oscillator Indicators (07:24 - 09:34)

Momentum: MACD, moving averages, Parabolic SAR.
Oscillators: RSI, Stochastic for overbought/oversold signals.
Divergences hint at reversals.
Volume Indicators and Market Structure (09:34 - 11:13)

Volume indicators reveal movement strength (e.g., VWAP, volume profiles).
Market structure: higher highs/lows = uptrend; lower highs/lows = downtrend.
Supply and Demand Zones (10:41 - 11:13)

Significant price movement levels act as potential entry zones.
Key Market Concepts (11:13 - 11:46)

Break of structure: price surpasses previous peaks.
Change of character: signals potential trend reversal.

input: What tools do I use for 2D and 3D Art? For sound  coding and all things game dev? Which tools should   you pick for your next game? It all comes down  to the idea of slowing down to go faster. Let's   start with 2d Art. So, first things first: Let's  talk about Aseprite. Some folks swear by it,   but in my humble opinion, this software  is overrated. (00:23) Why? Well, if you head over   to places like Pixel Joint and check out some  of the most jaw-dropping pixel art out there,   you're going to find out that Aseprite isn't the  tool that they are using to make those pixel art.   The main issue I have with Aseprite is that  it forces you to draw every single Pixel. And   believe it or not, that's not the go-to technique  used by top tier pixel artists and I know it may   sound counterintuitive because pixel art is all  about drawing pixels, right? but this is one of   those well-kept secrets in the world of pixel  art. We can delve deeper into it another time. (00:53) but just to demonstrate what I mean by this this  is how pixel art can be done outside of Aseprite:   I've set a color palette with some filters and  I'm just going to do one click with my mouse.   [one click with my mouse.] This is the result of  one click and now let's add some cracks here. I'm   going to take the brush tool and the pencil tool  and then yeah. (01:16) Let's tweak this sphere so it seems   like it's made of a different material. I would  love to see how long it would take to achieve   this sort of result with Aseprite. Sure Aseprite  is very easy to use and the alternative that I'm   going to talk here might take a bit more time  to master, but remember what we said: slow down   to go faster. (01:37) Although the idea of learning a new  software may seem intimidating, it can ultimately   help you work faster and produce higher quality  results. Now when it comes to 2D art it's hard   to beat the versatility of Photoshop. I've used  Photoshop in the past. It is a great software, but   I don't use it anymore. [I don't use it anymore].  Photoshop, it's like the Swiss army knife of art   software. You can create all sorts of art styles  with that. (02:00) In fact, many of the best pixel artists   actually use Photoshop for their craft. The main  catch is that is on the pricey side. Currently I   got two trusty tools that I use for 2D art: First  I have Photopea. It is a remarkable alternative to   Photoshop and I can't emphasize this enough it  is fantastic having used Photoshop for years I   can confidently say that Photopea offers almost  all the features you'd find in Photoshop. (02:23) You   can dabble in various art styles and play around  with layers blading options filters. You name,   it even if you're into pixel art, you can  restrict yourself to a pallet and Photopea   gots your back and best of all it costs zero USD  to use. Next up we have Krita. Now, it might be a   bit slower and havier in the system when you are  tinkering with filters, palletization, blending;   If we compare it to Photoshop or Photopea,  but it's still a stellar software. (02:50) Personally,   I use Krita for drawing and illustration,  especially when I'm using a drawing tablet.   Its brush controls are very good. It is also  possible to do animations in Krita: It has Nifty   features such as onion skinning, so that you can  see other frames while you're drawing a new frame   Krita can also be used for pixel-art, there's a  lot you can do with filters and palletization and   so on. (03:16) It is 20% more expensive than Photopea,  which means that you can get it for 0 dollars as   well. I use Krita for drawing and illustrations  using a drawing tablet and and when it's time   for Mouse based image editing I bring my art to  Photopea and I do most of the work there. Now what   do I use for design docks project management and  overall organization? Google Docs, Google Sheets,   and Google Slides. I admit these tools have no  aesthetic appeal. (03:38) Actually, they are ugly, but   they more than make up for it in functionality.  When you on the go and an idea strikes, you can   write it down from anywhere using your phone then  you can share collaborate annotate everything with   versioning of what changed and when so very simple  and effective. (03:54) Then we have Version Control I use   GIT and GitHub and for me this is a must. Trust  me, manually saving multiple versions of your   project for for every risk tweak you make will  lead to headaches in the long run. GIT may seem   complicated if you're new to it, but I believe  investing sometime to learn it well will pay   off big time down the road. Remember: slow down to  go faster. (04:15) Before we dive into the 3D tools I got   something to share with you: the Source-code of  my GameJam winning game. I've decided to make the   construct project available to you you will get a  behind the scenes look on how the game was set up,   how Marcos AI work, all the levels, all the  assets, and the nitty gritty details on how the   game works. (04:33) I'm creating a mailing list for the  folks who are interested in game development and   want to follow my journey as I bring this game to  Steam. And I want YOU to be a part of it. That's   why I'm offering you the actual source-project  complete with the assets, to open up the project,   run it and even modify it if you want. Sign up  in the list below and I will personally send you   the source-code of Awful Marco Bros. (04:52) Plus you  will see how user friendly the game engine I   use is. You will be able to open the project  without installing any software. All right,   now let's shift our Focus to 3d Art Tools. It has  been a while since I dipped my toes into 3d game   development. I've made some 3d assets of the game  you are seeing on the screen right now. This is a   game from 2008 and it was supposed to be a VR game  before Oculus Rift was a thing. (05:14) And as you can   guess this game never saw the light of day. While  I can't say I was particularly good at 3D art   back then, I'm eager to jump back in. Currently  I'm experimenting with 3D art and my next game   will likely incorporate some form of stylized  3D. First up we have Blockbench for modeling:   This tool can simplify the workflow for a specific  style of art I highly recommend checking out the   videos made by Brandon James Greer on this  subject. (05:40) The models created with Blockbench   have a distinct aesthetic that, in my opinion  fits perfectly with the kind of games that Indie   devs can create. As I mentioned in my previous  video, I wouldn't advise indie or solo devs to   chase after High-Fidelity Graphics; Instead opting  for a distinctive stylized 3d style could be your   best bet. (06:01) Now even though I'm leaning towards  Blockbench for 3d modeling Blender remains the   undisputable champion for rigging exporting  and editing all things 3d. So there's no way   around it Blender if you need 3d assets. Blender  is basically an essential part of any 3d artist   tool kit, unless you have very deep pockets  of course! So, distinctive stylized 3d look   is the strategy that I chose as a solo developer,  and while Blockbench may be my modeling tool of   choice I undoubtedly have to use Blender alongside  it. (06:26) For Audio I don't have much to say when it   comes to mixing and fine-tuning sound effects and  music tracks I use Audacity and I'm guessing most   of you are already familiar with Audacity.  For music I dabbed into some digital audio   workstation softwares in the past, however I'm not  planning on writing my own music at the moment,   and instead I'm using asset packs, royaltyfree  music, and from time to time teaming up with folks   that make music. (06:52) Game Engine: I've dedicated an  entire video to discuss my Game Engine of choice,   but here is a condensed version. Construct3 ticks  all the boxes for 2D Game Development. Also,   it boasts some basic 3D Features and most  importantly, it make me very productive. Plus it's   pretty decent for creating crossplatform games.  Programming Language: When it comes to coding,   TypeScript is a programming language I really  like. Plus I use it in my daily work. (07:12) It is   great not to have to context switch between  programming languag when I'm working on games   versus when I'm working in my daily job. I've  delv deeper into this topic in my previous video,   explaining why I prefer TypeScript over GDscript  and GML. So check out the video for more details   on that. The code editor that I use is Vscode. (07:31) Construct3 has this feature that exports all the   type definitions and the TS config of your project  in such a way that you can very easily use it in   Vscode to edit your code using autocomplete  for example. If you don't know vs code is   much lighter than its cousin Visual Studio, and it  has many extensions that you can use to customize   the editor and improve your workflow. Vscode also  plays nicely with Git. (07:52) While I personally prefer   using Git via the command line, those who are  getting started can have a much easier time using   it directly inside Vscode. And once again if you  are interested in following my journey bringing   an enhanced version of Awful Marco bros to Steam,  and also gain access to the project Source-code,   you can sign up for the meeting list. The link  is in the description. (08:11) And for those of you   curious to see these tools in action, stay  tuned for my next video. See you next time!.
output:
Introduction to Tools

The speaker discusses tools for 2D/3D art, coding, sound, and game development, emphasizing the philosophy of "slow down to go faster." (00:00)
Aseprite Critique

Aseprite is considered overrated because it focuses on drawing every pixel, which isn't the primary technique used by top-tier pixel artists. (00:23)
Preferred 2D Art Tools

Photopea: A free alternative to Photoshop with extensive features for various art styles, including pixel art. (02:00)
Krita: Ideal for drawing and animation, particularly with a tablet, though slower for filters and blending. (02:50)
Organization and Version Control

Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides: Used for design documents and project management. (03:38)
Git and GitHub: Essential for version control, despite a learning curve. (03:54)
3D Art Tools

Blockbench: Recommended for stylized 3D modeling, particularly for indie developers. (05:40)
Blender: Indispensable for rigging, exporting, and editing 3D assets. (06:01)
Audio Tools

Audacity: Used for sound effects and mixing. (06:26)
Music: Primarily uses asset packs and royalty-free music instead of composing. (06:52)
Game Engine and Programming

Construct3: Chosen for 2D development, cross-platform capabilities, and productivity. (06:52)
TypeScript and VS Code: Preferred for coding, with VS Code offering features like autocomplete and Git integration. (07:12, 07:31)
Sharing Resources

The speaker offers the source code for a game project ("Awful Marco Bros") and invites viewers to join a mailing list to access it. (04:15, 07:52)
Future Plans

Plans to incorporate stylized 3D art in upcoming projects and release more videos showcasing these tools in action. (05:14, 08:11)
